utterances: It's definitely one for the record books.
That's John Gordon, a restaurant analyst who runs Pacific Management Consulting Group.
In 2010 alone, 600 stores closed.
And he says the sudden loss of restaurants has left Quiznos without enough money to rebound with its own national advertising blitz.
So unfortunately you've gotten smaller, you can't or you don't advertise, you get smaller again.
It becomes a vicious circle, unfortunately.
And the smaller Quiznos got, the harder it became to pay off its massive debt.
And yesterday it gave up control of the company to one of its largest creditors, Avenue Capital.
The deal eliminates $300 million in debt and adds 150 million in new funding.
Franchise owner Andre Bonyadian says to turn Quiznos around, new owners will first need to open a meaningful dialogue with the franchisees.
That's where the success comes from.
And we are hoping that the new ownership will just do that, will work with us and listen to us, and it will be happily ever after.
And Bonyadian says that may be the chain's last hope.
For NPR News, I'm Ben Markus in Denver.
Four months after firing its CEO, Yahoo has a new leader.
Scott Thompson comes from eBay, where he ran PayPal - the system people use for purchases online.
Now, he faces a turnaround job, as NPR's Wendy Kaufman reports.
The Internet giant that pioneered a lot of what's cool on the Web has been struggling for a long time.
And while Yahoo still has more than 700 million users, its ad revenues are falling, while Facebook's and Google's are rising.
I think Yahoo just needs some clear focus to go after whatever it is.
Shar VanBoskirk is an analyst at Forrester Research.
She says leadership and direction have been in short supply at the company.
In Kansas City, Chicago and other cities, officials are making door-to-door well-being checks on older residents and those with health problems.
People are being asked to check on their neighbors, and cooling centers are open for people without air conditioning.
Still, hospitals around the Midwest are seeing scores of patients with heat-related illnesses, including heat stroke and dehydration.
The heat is putting a huge demand on the nation's power grid, leading to scattered power outages, and hot pavement is buckling on some highways.
The hot weather is also baking some crops.
Yeah so what happens when plants get heat stressed and water stressed is they get curly leaves like this.

Curtis Millsap owns and operates an organic farm outside of Springfield, Missouri, and he says this summer's heat is much earlier and much more intense than usual, leading to wilting lettuce and fewer vegetables.
Here you can see some of the blossoms that are kind of there's(ph) - they should stay on there and become cherry tomato - or yeah, tomatoes, and they're just falling off.
It's too hot for them.
For many farmers, the heat adds insult to injury.
Flooding and a cold wet spring led many to plant late.
Now corn, wheat and other crop yields might be even be smaller.
Dairy production is down too, as hot cows don't give as much milk.
And it's so hot in some areas, livestock are dropping dead.

At least 1,500 cattle in South Dakota died because of the heat, as did some dairy cows in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and thousands of chickens and turkeys on poultry farms from Kansas to North Carolina.

Temperatures are expected to cool a bit today in some parts of the Midwest, if you can call the upper 80s cool, but they will only rise in the East as the heat dome covering much of the country slowly moves that way.
David Schaper, NPR News, Chicago.
On March 1st, a big across-the-board spending cuts, known as the sequester, are set to hit almost every corner of federal spending.
Many are warning the consequences would be dire.
Sequestration is a reckless and a blunt tool that would force deep spending reductions across critical investments in R&D and education.
That was Peter McPherson, president of the Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities, speaking today here in Washington.
His is just the latest voice in a growing chorus now calling on Congress to head off the sequester.
If lawmakers don't act, there will also be political consequences.
NPR's Tamara Keith reports.
It started back in August in a post on House Speaker John Boehner's website.
Instead of calling it the sequester, the post called it the president's sequester.
Then last week, the speaker got up on the House floor and gave a three-minute speech, where he called it the president's sequester four times.
Now twice, the House has passed legislation to replace the president's sequester - to replace the president's sequester...
What started out as a sort of subtle language shift, by the end of the week became a full on rebranding campaign, complete with its own hashtag: Obamaquester.
Here's Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell earlier today on the Senate floor.
The House passed legislation to avert the Obama's sequester months ago.
But Senate Democrats have yet to pass an alternative bill that could actually go to conference.
The message: the Republican leadership, at least, doesn't like these automatic spending cuts.
And in case you're wondering, the sequester wasn't their idea.
To back this up, Boehner and his colleagues cite page 326 of the book ""The Price of Politics,"" by one of America's most well-known journalists.
I'm Bob Woodward, an associate editor at The Washington Post.
Woodward's book examines the fight over the debt ceiling back in the summer of 2011.
Republicans said they wouldn't raise the debt limit unless government spending was cut by the amount of the increase.
And if a bipartisan effort to find $1.2 trillion in cuts failed, Woodward says high-level White House aides had an idea.
It would be so Draconian neither side would let it happen.
On page 326, Woodward describes Jack Lew, then the president's budget director, pitching the idea to the Senate's Democratic leader.
Jack Lew said we have an idea for a trigger.
And Harry Reid, the Democratic leader asked skeptically, what's the idea.
And Lew said, sequestration.
Reid bent down and put his head between his knees almost as if he was going to throw up or was having a heart attack.
The bill ultimately passed the House and the Senate with overwhelming Republican support.
John Boehner and the majority of Republicans in Congress voted for it.
So yes, says Woodward...
Well, of course, it's the president's sequester.
But...
Of course, they all went along but we're now in the hole that they all dug for themselves.
Beyond the actual origins of the sequester idea, there's a reason Boehner and others in the Republican leadership are pushing hard on this.
Many rank-and-file Republicans are perfectly willing to let the sequester go ahead, or at least lock in cuts of the same size.
Because of this, if the sequester does happen, Republicans risk getting the blame.
South Carolina Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, who's backing a bill to replace the cuts this year, says his party deserves the blame.
We have our fingerprints as Republicans on this proposal, on this sequestration idea.
It was the president's idea, according to Bob Woodward's book.
But we as the Republican Party agreed to it.
He must not have gotten the memo about the hashtag Obamaquester.
It's safe to say, though, that if actually happens on March 1st, and if the dire predictions become a reality, there will be plenty of blame to go around.
Tamara Keith, NPR News, the Capitol.
And does that exist in Russia, Water of the Week?
And you know, if you're a diehard baseball fan, you live and you die with statistics.

The stats are - people comparing one player with the other, the batting averages and the different eras, you know, different dead ball era, home run era, they tell everything, you know - the RBIs, everything else.
But how do you consider your favorite players' VORP?
Your VORP?
That's a number representing his value to a team over an easily available replacement player.
How do you figure out whether that player is more valuable to your team than getting someone else?
Or how do you figure out the numbers involved in putting your favorite old-time player in a time machine dropping them off with your favorite present day team?
How do you compare Babe Ruth and present-day player from Pujols today?
How do you compare the two?
How do you determine if your team is wasting its closing pitcher?
How - yeah, you know, one of the things about baseball you talk about, when do you bring in the closing pitcher?
How much money should we spend on that closing pitcher?
How do we know we're not wasting our money?
My next guest says that the closer should be left in longer, something that is going against the rule of baseball today.
And he has done the math.
